commentBody:
Brilliant 

The trees were relatively obvious and I was quick to realize they were the key.

But even then I wondered if there was something about being able to see the Forest.

Until it was solved…I didn’t see it coming.
Loved the theme . And "Mars with Bars" was the clue of the week for me.
This played like a Tuesday for me.

The pièce de résistance actually is the fact that all the words minus their covered-up initial or final letter, are themselves the names of trees or plants:  ASH, FIR, PEAR, APPLE, ELM and LOTUS.  

LOTUS flowers are a real thing; there is a mythical thing called the LOTUS tree mentioned in the Odyssey.

The Thursday gimmick was pretty pedestrian.  I give the puzzle high marks, however, for highlighting John McPhee.  I have an entire shelf full of his books, some of which I’ve read multiple times.  He is a fine writer with tremendous  intellectual curiosity, and he’s capable of making anything  from geological theory to oranges interesting.  My favorite of his books is Coming Into The Country, which explores aspects of the state from a variety of perspectives: environmental, political and personal.  His depiction of life among the characters who came to the state to live away from civilization is fascinating.
Fun one, I enjoyed the theme a lot! And Mars with bars was brilliant, well done ;)

This was fun. I did recognize that the "treed" words without the tree were... trees (starting with ELM(O).

I can't say i recall ever seeing a NYT grid that did not have either diagonal or bilateral symmetry. Not a complaint, just an observation.
For 23A, it should be 1988, not 1998. The going back to cali in 1998 would have been Notorious B.I.G.
Fun puzzle but there’s an error in the clue for 23 Across. “Going Back to Cali” is from 1988, not 1998.

Remarkably executed theme.  Three spellings that seemed wrong and made me question my third grade Spelling Bee award - did everyone get that award just for showing up?  ISOSCELES, SCHWEPPES, PAULO. 

Also, many bonus points for including John MCPHEE.
Easy puzzle even though I had no idea what the gimmick was.

Seems a little inelegant that sometimes the missing letter is the end of an answer and other times the start of one, but I get that it’s necessary due to the tree shape the “forest” forms.  I guess it’s one of those puzzles that begins to make more sense once you find the revealer, and before that, you might flail around a bit.

This puzzle was more clever than I realized!  It's good I read the Wordplay to see the 'forest'.  Nice!  (I wish our forests could be better protected against the ravages of shortsighted greed.)

Meanwhile, an observation.  I claimed Wednesday's puzzle felt like a 'Thursday'.  My solve time was nearly identical for these two puzzles, around eighteen minutes.  And! I had the exact same number of cheats, eight!
I done did this puzz
very well done. loved the tree names worked into the shortened answers.

Finally lost my streak. A lot of nasty crossings here.

ACTIN/TUN
GILA/ILE

MCPHEE/FARRIERS/MARNER was what did me in. Was pretty confident in the M and brute-forced the other crossing. Twice actually after I noticed that I misspelled ISOSCELES and missed it on my check since BANC is a real word. I did settle on the R before I clicked Check Puzzle.

My mistake? Misspelling PAoLO/DoPLO.

Alas
Lots of fun but I realized when I filled in ELMO as E-L-MO that I was barking up the wrong tree...

Enjoyed the Mars with bars as others did. The Marner/McPhee cross was not my favorite. Farrier and thither were hard for me as an intermediate solver. Love the inclusion of Schweppes. That takes me back.

Oh, dear, there's a few American brand names in this one, too.

But a very different trick or theme. I quite liked it.
Branching out to new puzzle styles.
Broke a long streak thanks to Sao Paulo and Duplo.  I'm pretty annoyed to say the least.
Tree-mendous

commentBody: Hope no one grew B(alder) scratching their head over this, nor had to S(oak) in a cool tub to calm down, nor suffered any spasms of the S(pine) from crouching over their device.

Fun puzzle, especially after yesterday's unsolvable mess (for me, at least).

2. Surprised to find out that color TV was commercially available as early as 1953, but most color programs started in the 60s

Last thing for me was TUN /ACTIN pair which brought a fond memory that my mother-in-law taught me the word TUN many years ago during one of our many co-solves of  crossword puzzles. That was the first and last time (until today) that I'd ever heard the word...
Very cute reveal after solving. Loved it.

“Going Back to Cali” 

“Hmm, I don’t think so”

Nice animation. 

Congratulations to the constructors on a clever debut.

Weelll...

Congratulations to the Kolkowitz team. Geez, to have a family member call, much less construct a puzzke together. Well done.

Just a little conflicted here - wonder if anyone else is of a like mind? The asymmetrical grid, the vestigial tree are fine, yet there was a little dissonance that still niggles even after solving.
The gimmick revealed itself cleanly, and the unfamiliar Mr. MCPHEE filled via crosses and a lucky guess. I enjoyed the doublecross of hiding the forest in a wonky grid. So why the disquiet? Mayhaps my equilibrium is off?

Xwordinfo notes a scant 43 grids with no / unusual symmetry in the 'modern' era. The first one dates from 1994. So 365pa x 31 ys, over 11,000 grids offered up by Times constructors which have some sort of symmetry, and only 43 with a prickly pattern? Ah, that must be it. Angst averted.

One moment changes a day, one day changes a life, one life can change the world.

Anyhoo, go out and hug that family member you've been meaning to call.

I think I must be aging out of these puzzles. 

Between toys that were invented when I was in my 40s, to rappers whose names are a complete mystery due to their torture of the language, to  actors that I couldn't care less about because all they do are super-hero movies (which I abhor).

I like trees - I liked the puzzle.

I'm so pleased I saw each individual tree name, and also latched on to F-O-R-E-S-T being the missing letters. So I guess I saw it all, the forest and the trees. I feel so accomplished! The real accomplishment, though, is that of the Kolkowitz brothers. Brilliant execution, having the FOREST letters cascading down, in order, from top to bottom and left to right. Bravo! On the other hand, that acronym has always put me off: It’s possible that I just don’t like the whole SCOTUS/POTUS/FLOTUS thing, but it’s more likely that FLOTUS is just too close to flatus for me.

A couple of observations on SAO PAULO. (No diacritics on my iPhone keyboard)
Firstly, Portuguese and Spanish are different languages with different spelling rules. A real trap for those more familiar with the latter. 
Secondly, when, having completed the puzzle, I decided to check on Googles the second suggestion after I had typed “Sao” was São Paulo. Obviously many other people had the same idea. 
Oh, and yes, I also started SAO PAoLO. It was the gimme DUPLO that set me right.
What a fun puzzle!

Could somebody please explain the BRUNO Mars clue to me? He sings bars, the column says... What does that mean?

What are EES, MIT grads?

What's an SST?

Also, I know the US date format when using days, months and years is mm/dd/yyyy but I don't get 10/03. Is that October 2003 or March 2010? In Polish we tend to use Roman numerals for months to avoid such confusion, or we just make the Herculean effort of writing two more digits to denote the year in full.

"Felix Randal the farrier, O is he dead then? . . ." The beginning of one of my favorite poems. Here is the closing stanza which gets me every time. It portrays the recently decayed and deceased man in his younger days. "How far from then forethought of, all thy more boisterous years, When thou at the random grim forge, powerful amidst peers, Didst fettle for the great grey drayhorse his bright and battering sandal!" The complete Hopkins poem, (only four stanzas), is here: https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44394/felix-randal

I guess with all the coastline length discussion going on, I'll take a shot at explaining something I find fascinating.

According to chaos theory, all coastlines are infinitely long.

Imagine actually doing the measurement.  You take a string 100 ft long, say, and lay it out time after time going around the coast you're measuring.

You'll come up with an answer, but it's certainly going to be off, because most of the time the 100ft segment didn't fit cleanly along the shoreline.  

So you use a shorter string, and you'll get a longer answer.  But you've still missed some nooks and crannies.

So you go with a shorter string, and get a longer shoreline.  But you've still missed some smaller nooks and crannies. Eventually, you'll get down to microscopic errors and longer lengths, right down to and beyond the atomic a subatomic levels, all the time getting longer.

(At a certain point this all breaks down, if truly works only in continuous media, unlike ours which breaks up into discrete particles.

So what you come down to is that shorelines have infinite length, even though they enclose a finite area.

The world is really interesting, if you can stomach much of its misery.

Wow - what a beautiful theme!! A smile spread across my face as it came into focus. 

A thoroughly enjoyable Thursday :)

So elegant, having the theme answers each be two words, one a clue to crack, and the other a theme-affirming type of tree.

So original, coming up with this idea in the first place.  It’s never been done before.  Wow!

So sweet, having the theme echoed by centering the grid with a visual tree.

Such admirable chutzpah, sending a renegade asymmetrical submission to the Times when you’ve never had a puzzle published there before.

Such a lovely touch, sprinkling beauty into the box, with ESPOUSES, MNEME, THITHER, SOLACES, BEARNAISE, ISOSCELES, MCPHEE, ABLOOM, and SEMINAL.

All this in a NYT debut, and what promise it portends.  I so hope to see more from you, Ilan and Shimon.  This was eye-opening as well as entertaining, and thank you so much.  What a boost!

MNEME has released in me so many memories of the Muses that I couldn't refrain from these musings.

MNEME is one of the "original" three Boeotian muses.  She isn't one of the nine Muses I learned as a young lover of Greek mythology.  (You know, the ones that include Calliope and Terpsichore, and Clio and Erato [beloved of cruciverbalists]).  However, the mother of these nine was Mnemosyne, the personification (or rather apotheosis) of Memory.

How wonderful, I thought, that all the Arts are viewed as something divine and dependent on Memory.  And, when one learns of Homer's tremendous feat of being able to recite the Iliad and Odyssey from his capacious memory, you begin to understand.

And let us remember that both "music" and "museum" originate with the Muses.

If we go by most laypeople’s’ definition of “coastline,” MI beats out everyone but AK quite handily with 3000+ miles.

But I digress. Great puzzle, Kolkowitz(es? i?)!
Amazing!! What a fantastic feat.

Also, it's a shame that LOTUS is the one theme entry that isnt a tree. Otherwise enjoyed the puzzle, but these two things irritated me personally.

@Chris  Actually, Maine has 3,478 coastline miles (plus a couple thousand more miles when you include freshwater shoreline). Beats out California and Florida.

@Chris @MB et al The problem is there’s no standard way to measure coastlines. The measured length varies according to the level of detail used in measuring. Maine, with its “jagged” coast, can beat Florida, with its relatively “smooth“ coast, if the units of measurement are small enough, but comes up short if they are big enough. Also worth noting - Great rappers are said to “have bars”. 

I feel like this phrase has taken on a life of its own but it was almost certainly originally based on the music theory you mentioned.

“Bar” in music = 4 beats (in 4/4 time).

“Bar” in rap = One line of lyrics that fits into those 4 beats.

Conversationally, I feel like most have lost sight of this and rappers are simply said to “have bars” if they are good at improvising creative, powerful lyrics.

@Nora et al.:

The Wikipedia entry under “lotus tree,” uses Homer’s lotus as an example because it (lazily) uses a 19th c. dictionary citation. I checked: The latter uses Pope’s translation of The Odyssey. Pope took a lot of liberties in his (very beautiful) translations: What he calls a “lotus-tree,” Homer simply calls “lotus” (lōtós), and nowhere in the context does he suggest it’s a tree. 

Now, that doesn’t mean that the lotus tree is mythical. E.g. Strabo mentions “lotus trees” with some frequency (dendra lōtoús), Athenaeus writes of the “tree-like lotus” (lōtós ho déndrinos) and Pliny the Elder, drawing on Theophrastus and Herodotus, and ever the fastidious botanist and ethnographer, clearly describes the lotus tree as opposed to the marsh plant: 

“In Africa, lotuses also grow which are like trees…”

vs.:

“There is also the Egyptian lotus, found in marshes, similar to the cyprus but with broader leaves. It has its own pleasant flavor when imbibed, and its root is sweet…”

As @Nora writes, the lotus tree definitely exists, although it’s probably not what Homer had in mind. 

Now Ovid, on the other hand… But this is already too long of a post.

@JohnWM

You're right. A lot of style manuals treat acronyms differently from initialisms. If an acronym is a familar word (laser), no caps; if it's a familiar proper noun (Nasa), initial caps; but initialisms generally stay in allcaps. It's to do with reducing the distracting effect of capitalized words on a page of text. But different publishers will have different rules for different acronyms.

@Momerlyn

Sure. But among initialisms that are not registered, house styles vary. For the measure of pressure, one encounters both PSI and psi, for instance, depending on how anxious the publisher is about confusion with the Greek letter. For times on the twelve-hour clock, one sees both "am/pm" and "AM/PM", with the additional option of small caps.

You enter your credit card PIN, you can write "pin numbers" tautologically, but I don't think I've ever seen "Pin", despite its status as an acronym.

(I know that Zipper was actually trademarked for a while, originally as a name for quick-fastening waterproof overshoes, but then I collect these gems of word origin---my favourite bit of obscurity is the fact that "coach", as a form of transport, gets its name from the town of Kocs in Hungary.)
